title: Race Against Time: Fixing a Critical Bug
hook: At 2am, two weeks before our biggest launch, I discovered a race condition in our data sync layer that would have double-charged every customer order.

situation.summary: Two weeks before our largest product launch, I stumbled upon a race condition during a routine stress test using Locust. This critical bug in the data sync layer had the potential to double-charge customers for every transaction.
evidence: Using Locust to simulate 1000 concurrent users
Replicating the issue within a 50ms window

obstacles.summary: The race condition was elusive, requiring multiple attempts to reproduce under high concurrency. With the launch deadline looming, we faced exhaustion during the 72-hour incident response period, relying on teamwork and determination to stay focused.
evidence: Hour 72 exhaustion and Sarah bringing coffee at 3am

actions.summary: I immediately pulled in Sarah from platform, Marcus from the orders team, and Dev, a contractor familiar with the legacy system. Marcus implemented a Redis lock and added monitoring within minutes, giving the team confidence as we traced the issue across three independent services.
evidence: Marcus implemented Redis lock and monitoring

results.summary: The fix was deployed at 4:17am on day three, and validation confirmed the issue was resolved. Post-migration, deployment frequency improved dramatically from bi-weekly to 5-10 times per day, and the runbook I wrote is still used to prevent similar crises.
evidence: Deployment frequency improved from bi-weekly to 5-10x daily

reasoning: The story was structured to highlight the urgency of the crisis, the technical and human challenges faced, and the decisive actions taken under pressure. Specific evidence was included to showcase the stakes, teamwork, and quantified outcomes, ensuring credibility and impact.
